raw.author: Walter Benjamin
contexts: Thus, Walter Benjamin—whose Surrealist sensibility is the most profound of anyone's on record—was a passionate collector of quotations.

As Walter Benjamin observed in 1934, in an address delivered in Paris at the Institute for the Study of Fascism, the camera “is now incapable of photographing a tenement or a rubbish-heap without transfiguring it.
Another criterion which they can share is the quality of presence, which Walter Benjamin considered the defining characteristic of the work of art.
The result of mechanical reproduction, Benjamin says, is to “put the copy of the original into situations which would be out of reach for the original itself.”
commentaries: The author references Walter Benjamin as a thinker with a profound Surrealist sensibility and a collector of quotations, connecting his practices to photographic and historical collection.
The author cites Walter Benjamin's 1934 address, quoting his observation that photography inherently beautifies its subjects, turning even poverty into an object of aesthetic enjoyment.
The author references Walter Benjamin's concept of 'presence' as a defining characteristic of art, applying it to the evaluation of photography.
The author quotes Benjamin on the effects of mechanical reproduction, using his idea to discuss the aura of photographs in museum display.

goodreads_match.description:
Euclides da Cunha's classic account of the brutal campaigns against religious mystic Antonio Conselheiro has been called the Bible of Brazilian nationality.
"Euclides da Cunha went on the campaigns [against Conselheiro] as a journalist and what he returned with and published in 1902 is still unsurpassed in Latin American literature. commentaries: The author cites Hawthorne's novel to illustrate an early literary observation about photography's capacity to reveal hidden truths beyond mere surface depiction, contrasting it with painting.

raw.title: Swann's Way
raw.author: Marcel Proust
contexts: One can’t imagine the Overture to Swann’s Way ending with the narrator’s coming across a snapshot of the parish church at Combray and the savoring of that visual crumb, instead of the taste of the humble madeleine dipped in tea, making an entire part of his past spring into view.
commentaries: The author uses Proust's novel as an example to contrast the deep, sensory-triggered involuntary memory with the shallow, visual recall offered by photographs.

goodreads_match.title: Swann's Way
goodreads_match.description:
Swann's Way tells two related stories, the first of which revolves around Marcel, a younger version of the narrator, and his experiences in, and memories of, the French town Combray. Inspired by the "gusts of memory" that rise up within him as he dips a Madeleine into hot tea, the narrator discusses his fear of going to bed at night. He is a creature of habit and dislikes waking up in the middle of the night not knowing where he is.
He claims that people are defined by the objects that surround them and mus...

raw.title: The Pencil of Nature
raw.author: William Henry Fox Talbot
contexts: In his book of photographs The Pencil of Nature (1844-46), Fox Talbot relates that the idea of photography came to him in 1833, on the Italian Journey that had become obligatory for Englishmen of inherited wealth like himself, while making some sketches of the landscape at Lake Como.
commentaries: The author references Talbot's book to describe the origin of the photographic idea and its conceptualization as an impersonal, natural form of notation, distinct from artistic intervention.

goodreads_match.title: The Pencil of Nature
goodreads_match.description: First commercially published book illustrated with photographs, issued in six parts between 1844 and 1846. It demonstrated the potential of the calotype process and contained 24 original photographic prints.

goodreads_match.title: Duineser Elegien
goodreads_match.description: A cycle of ten elegies by Rainer Maria Rilke, considered his masterwork and a pinnacle of German-language poetry. They are profound meditations on human existence, love, death, and the relationship between the visible and invisible worlds.

raw.title: Pierre
raw.author: Herman Melville
contexts: In Melville’s Pierre, published at the start of the decade, the hero, another fevered champion of voluntary isolation, “considered with what infinite readiness now, the most faithful portrait of any one could be taken by the Daguerreotype, whereas in former times a faithful portrait was only within the power of the moneyed, or mental aristocrats of the earth.
commentaries: The author cites Melville's novel to illustrate the 19th-century fear that photography democratized and thus demeaned portraiture, leveling uniqueness.

goodreads_match.title: PIERRE: OR, THE AMBIGUITIES. (Annotated)
goodreads_match.description:
THERE are some strange summer mornings in the country, when he who is but a sojourner from the city shall early walk forth into the fields, and be wonder-smitten with the trance-like aspect of the green and golden world. Not a flower stirs; the trees forget to wave; the grass itself seems to have ceased to grow; and all Nature, as if suddenly become conscious of her own profound mystery, and feeling no refuge from it but silence, sinks into this wonderful and indescribable repose.

goodreads_match.title: Mimesis: The Representation of Reality in Western Literature

raw.author: Reich
contexts: According to Reich, the masochist’s taste for pain does not spring from a love of pain but from the hope of procuring, by means of pain, a strong sensation; those handicapped by emotional or sensory analgesia only prefer pain to not feeling anything at all.
commentaries: The author cites Reich's psychological theory to explain the motivation behind seeking painful experiences, contrasting it with another explanation later in the text.

raw.title: Invitation to a Beheading
raw.author: Vladimir Nabokov
contexts: In Nabokov’s Invitation to a Beheading (1938), the prisoner Cincinnatus is shown the “photohoroscope” of a child cast by the sinister M’sieur Pierre: an album of photographs of little Emmie as an infant, then a small child, then pre-pubescent, as she is now, then—by retouching and using photographs of her mother—of Emmie the adolescent, the bride, the thirty-year-old, concluding with a photograph at age forty, Emmie on her deathbed.
Something like this is suggested in Nabokov’s Invitation to a Beheading.
commentaries: The author references Nabokov's novel to present a fictional artifact that parodies both the work of time and the work of photography, showing how photographs can depersonalize and mock-possess the future.
The author references Nabokov's novel as a literary portrait of a model totalitarian state where photography is the omnipresent art, linking it to a future dictatorship centered on 'the interesting.'

goodreads_match.title: Invitation to a Beheading
goodreads_match.description: A novel by Vladimir Nabokov originally published in Russian in 1938 as 'Priglashenie na kazn'. It tells the story of Cincinnatus C., a man sentenced to death in a surreal totalitarian state for the crime of 'gnostical turpitude'.

raw.author: Plato
contexts: Humankind lingers unregenerately in Plato’s cave
and philosophers since Plato have tried to loosen our dependence on images by evoking the standard of an image-free way of apprehending the real.
In Plato’s Cave
commentaries: The author references Plato's allegory of the cave as a metaphor for humanity's relationship with images, specifically photographs.
The author references Plato as a foundational philosopher who critiqued reliance on images, setting up a historical contrast for the discussion of photography.
The author references Plato as a source of ideas, using the allegory of the cave as a section title, implying a philosophical framework for understanding photography.

raw.author: Proust
contexts: One can’t possess reality, one can possess (and be possessed by) images—as, according to Proust, most ambitious of voluntary prisoners, one can’t possess the present but one can possess the past.
commentaries: The author references Proust's ideas, likely from 'In Search of Lost Time', to draw an analogy between possessing images and possessing the past.

raw.author: Breton
contexts: Breton starts his essay of 1920 on Max Ernst by calling the practice of automatic writing “a true photography of thought,” the camera being regarded as “a blind instrument” whose superiority in “the imitation of appearances” had “dealt a mortal blow to the old modes of expression, in painting as well in poetry.”
commentaries: The author references Breton's ideas to show the Surrealist advocacy for photography as a liberating, impersonal form of expression that transcends the personal.

commentaries: The author references Jack Kerouac's introduction to describe the emotional and surreal quality captured in Robert Frank's photographic work, framing it as an anti-scientific inventory of America.

raw.author: Laszlo Moholy-Nagy
contexts:
Thus in the photographic camera we have the most reliable aid to a beginning of objective vision. Everyone will be compelled to see that which is optically true, is explicable in its own terms, is objective, before he can arrive at any possible subjective position. This will abolish that pictorial and imaginative association pattern which has remained unsuperseded for centuries and which has been stamped upon our vision by great individual painters. We have—through a hundred years of photography and two decades of film—been enormously enriched in this respect. We may say that we see the world with entirely different eyes. Nevertheless, the total result to date amounts to little more than a visual encyclopaedic achievement. This is not enough. We wish to produce systematically, since it is important for life that we create new relationships.
—Laszlo Moholy-Nagy (1925)
commentaries: The author cites Moholy-Nagy's argument that photography enables objective vision, overturning painterly traditions, but remains merely encyclopedic without systematic creation of new relationships.

raw.title: Painting, Photography, Film
raw.author: Moholy-Nagy
contexts: In his book Painting, Photography, Film (1925) Moholy-Nagy praises the camera for imposing “the hygiene of the optical,” which will eventually “abolish that pictorial and imaginative association pattern…which has been stamped upon our vision by great individual painters.”
commentaries: The author cites Moholy-Nagy's book to illustrate the Bauhaus view of photography as an impersonal, hygienic medium that can cleanse vision of painterly influences.

goodreads_match.title: Painting, Photography, Film
goodreads_match.description: A foundational Bauhaus text exploring the relationships between visual media, where Moholy-Nagy argues for photography's capacity to create new ways of seeing distinct from traditional painting.

goodreads_match.title: Brassai: Paris By Night
goodreads_match.description: Roaming Paris streets by night in the early 1930s, Brassa created arresting images of the city's dramatic nocturnal landscape. First published in French in 1932, this new edition brings one of Brassa's finest works back into print. The back alleys, metro stations, and bistros he photographed are at turns hauntingly empty or peopled by prostitutes, laborers, thugs, and lovers. "Paris by Night" is a stunning portrait of nighttime in the City of Light, as captured by its most articulate observer. 62 photos.

goodreads_match.title: Naked City
goodreads_match.description: For Naked City, his first collection, Weegee cruised the streets of 1940s New York in the wee hours in search of the sensational. Lewd, louche, licentious but always brimming with life (except when brimming with death), Weegee's photographs have endured decades of modern art criticism and are again enjoying a much-deserved cult revival.

raw.author: Walt Whitman
contexts: As Walt Whitman gazed down the democratic vistas of culture, he tried to see beyond the difference between beauty and ugliness, importance and triviality.
If (in Whitman’s words) “each precise object or condition or combination or process exhibits a beauty,” it becomes superficial to single out some things as beautiful and others as not.

The epigraph for a book of Walker Evans’s photographs published by the Museum of Modern Art is a passage from Whitman that sounds the theme of American photography’s most prestigious quest: “I do not doubt but the majesty & beauty of the world are latent in any iota of the world…I do not doubt there is far more in trivialities, insects, vulgar persons, slaves, dwarfs, weeds, rejected refuse, than I have supposed….”
Instead of showing identity between things which are different (Whitman’s democratic vista), everybody is shown to look the same.
Arbus’s view that self-revelation is a continuous, evenly distributed process is another way of maintaining the Whitmanesque imperative: treat all moments as of equal consequence.
the Whitmanesque appetites have turned pious
They might continue to practice the atomistic visual stenography inspired by Whitman.
But, without Whitman’s delirious powers of synthesis, what they documented was discontinuity, detritus, loneliness, greed, sterility.
What we have left of Whitman’s discredited dream of cultural revolution are paper ghosts and a sharp-eyed witty program of despair.
commentaries: The author references Walt Whitman as a prophet of cultural revolution who sought to transcend traditional aesthetic discriminations.
The author quotes Whitman's words to illustrate the idea that beauty is inherent in all things, influencing photographic aesthetics.
The author notes that a passage from Whitman serves as the epigraph for a Walker Evans photography book, highlighting Whitman's influence on the quest to find beauty in trivialities.
The author contrasts Arbus's photographic approach with Whitman's poetic vision of democratic inclusivity, likely referencing his poetry collections like Leaves of Grass.
The author describes Arbus's photographic philosophy as aligning with a 'Whitmanesque imperative' to treat all moments as equally important.
The author references Whitman as a source of cultural and aesthetic ideals in photography, noting a shift from his affirmative vision to a more pious or patronizing stance.
The author describes how photographers adopted a fragmented, detailed style of visual documentation inspired by Whitman's approach.
The author contrasts later photographers' work with Whitman's ability to synthesize and unify, attributing to him a capacity for cohesive vision that was lost.
The author presents Whitman's dream of cultural revolution as having failed, leaving behind only remnants and a cynical outlook in contemporary photography.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: The Decisive Moment: Photography of Henri Cartier-Bresson
goodreads_match.title: The Decisive Moment: Photography of Henri Cartier-Bresson

goodreads_match.title: Mrs. McGinty's Dead
goodreads_match.description:
An old widow is brutally killed in the parlour of her cottage...
Mrs McGinty died from a brutal blow to the back of her head. Suspicion fell immediately on her shifty lodger, James Bentley, whose clothes revealed traces of the victim's blood and hair. Yet something was amiss: Bentley just didn't look like a murderer.
Poirot believed he could save the man from the gallows - what he didn't realise was that his own life was now in great danger...

raw.author: Fernand Leger
contexts:
The war had thrust me, as a soldier, into the heart of a mechanical atmosphere. Here I discovered the beauty of the fragment. I sensed a new reality in the detail of a machine, in the common object. I tried to find the plastic value of these fragments of our modern life. I rediscovered them on the screen in the close-ups of objects which impressed and influenced me.
—Fernand Leger (1923)
commentaries: The author includes Leger's personal account of discovering aesthetic value in mechanical fragments and everyday objects, influenced by cinematic close-ups.

Delacroix's Journal is one of the great documents in art history, a magnificent work of literature as well as vital documentary source for scholars and students. raw.author: Baudelaire
contexts: according to the splenetic description of Baudelaire, “our squalid society” became narcissistically entranced by Daguerre’s “cheap method of disseminating a loathing for history.”

the ragpicker, who was one of Baudelaire’s favorite figures for the modern poet: “Everything that the big city threw away, everything it lost, everything it despised, everything it crushed underfoot, he catalogues and collects.. He sorts things out and makes a wise choice; he collects, like a miser guarding a treasure, the refuse which will assume the shape of useful or gratifying objects between the jaws of the goddess of Industry.”
For Baudelaire, photography was painting’s “mortal enemy”
—Baudelaire Life itself is not the reality. We are the ones who put life into stones and pebbles.

The author cites Baudelaire's view that photography was a mortal enemy to painting.

raw.title: The Magic Mountain
raw.author: Thomas Mann
contexts: To Hofrat Behrens, in The Magic Mountain, the pulmonary X-rays of his patients are diagnostic tools. To Hans Castorp... “Clavdia’s X-ray portrait... is the most precious of trophies.”
commentaries: The author cites Mann's novel to contrast the clinical and erotic meanings a photographic image (an X-ray) can hold for different characters.

goodreads_match.title: The Magic Mountain
goodreads_match.description: In this dizzyingly rich novel of ideas, Mann uses a sanatorium in the Swiss Alps, a community devoted exclusively to sickness, as a microcosm for Europe, which in the years before 1914 was already exhibiting the first symptoms of its own terminal irrationality. The Magic Mountain is a monumental work of erudition and irony, sexual tension and intellectual ferment, a book that pulses with life in the midst of death.

raw.author: James Agee
contexts: Walker Evans’s photographs were accompanied by eloquent prose written (sometimes overwritten) by James Agee, which aimed to deepen the reader’s empathy with the sharecroppers’ lives.
commentaries: The author describes Agee's textual contribution to the referenced book as aiming to create empathy.

raw.title: The American Scene
raw.author: Henry James
contexts: "He doesn’t know, he can’t say, before the facts," Henry James wrote in The American Scene (1907), "and he doesn’t even want to know or to say; the facts themselves loom, before the understanding, in too large a mass for a mere mouthful: it is as if the syllables were too numerous to make a legible word."
commentaries: The author quotes Henry James to illustrate the overwhelming and inscrutable nature of American reality, which resists straightforward classification or scientific understanding.

raw.title: Le Pere Goriot
raw.author: Honoré de Balzac
contexts: The passage that Auerbach analyzes from the beginning of Le Pere Goriot (1834)—Balzac is describing the dining room of the Vauquer pension at seven in the morning and the entry of Madame Vauquer—could hardly be more explicit (or proto-Proustian).
commentaries: The author cites a specific passage from Balzac's novel as analyzed by Auerbach to illustrate a point about descriptive realism.

goodreads_match.title: Le Père Goriot
goodreads_match.description: " Un brave homme - pension bourgeoise, 600 francs de rente - s'etant depouille pour ses filles qui toutes deux ont 50 000 livres de rente, mourant comme un chien. " Telle est l'indication qu'on peut lire dans l'album de Balzac qui contient le germe du Pere Goriot. Mais ce roman est bien autre chose que le recit d'une agonie. C'est l'education sentimentale " de Rastignac, jeune provincial monte a Paris, son apprentissage de la vie, de la societe et des hommes. C'est aussi le portrait d'une ville livree au pl...

raw.title: East 100th Street
raw.author: Bruce Davidson
contexts: Instead of the chutzpa of “the other half,” we get, say, East 100th Street (Bruce Davidson’s book of Harlem photographs published in 1970).
commentaries: The author cites Davidson's book as a contemporary example where photographers limit their subject to a specific area, continuing the tradition of documenting hidden truths.

goodreads_match.title: East 100th Street
goodreads_match.description: Photobook documenting life in a Harlem tenement block, considered a landmark work of social documentary photography.

raw.author: Edward Weston
contexts: —Edward Weston I attempt, through much of my work, to animate all things—even so-called “inanimate” objects—with the spirit of man.

Most modern reproducers of life, even including the camera, really repudiate it. We gulp down evil, choke at good.

raw.title: Jude the Obscure
raw.author: Thomas Hardy
contexts: In Jude the Obscure it is Jude’s discovery that Arabella has sold the maple frame with the photograph of himself in it which he gave her on their wedding day that signifies to Jude “the utter death of every sentiment in his wife”...
commentaries: The author cites Hardy's novel as an example where the destruction or disposal of a photograph is treated as a profound emotional rejection.

goodreads_match.title: Jude the Obscure
goodreads_match.description: In 1895 Hardy's final novel, the great tale of Jude The Obscure, sent shockwaves of indignation rolling across Victorian England. Hardy had dared to write frankly about sexuality and to indict the institutions of marriage, education, and religion. But he had, in fact, created a deeply moral work. The stonemason Jude Fawley is a dreamer; his is a tragedy of unfulfilled aims. With his tantalizing cousin Sue Bridehead, the last and most extraordinary of Hardy's heroines, Jude takes on the world and discovers,....

raw.title: Antlitz der Zeit (The Face of Our Time)

commentaries: The author mentions the publication and subsequent destruction of Sander's book by the Nazis, noting it as part of his national-portrait project.

goodreads_match.title: Antlitz der Zeit
goodreads_match.description: A landmark photobook by August Sander, featuring 60 portraits from his monumental project 'People of the 20th Century,' categorizing German society by profession and social type. The book was banned and its printing plates destroyed by the Nazi regime in 1936.

raw.title: Leaves of Grass
raw.author: Walt Whitman
contexts: The Great American Cultural Revolution heralded in the preface to the first edition of Leaves of Grass (1855) didn’t break out, which has disappointed many but surprised none.
commentaries: The author cites the preface to Whitman's 'Leaves of Grass' as heralding a cultural revolution that failed to materialize.

goodreads_match.title: Leaves of Grass
goodreads_match.description: Whitman is today regarded as America's Homer or Dante, and his work the touchstone for literary originality in the New World. In Leaves of Grass, he abandoned the rules of traditional poetry - breaking the standard metred line, discarding the obligatory rhyming scheme, and using the vernacular. Emily Dickinson condemned his sexual and physiological allusions as `disgraceful', but Emerson saw the book as the `most extraordinary piece of wit and wisdom that America has yet contributed'. A century later it is....

raw.title: Port of New York
raw.author: Paul Rosenfeld
contexts: In his florid, brilliant book of essays, Port of New York (1924), Paul Rosenfeld hailed Stieglitz as one “of the great affirmers of life.
This is the theme stated so eloquently in the finest essay ever written in praise of photography, Paul Rosenfeld’s chapter on Stieglitz in Port of New York.
commentaries: The author references Paul Rosenfeld's book 'Port of New York' for its praise of Alfred Stieglitz as a life-affirmer through photography.
The author praises Rosenfeld's essay as the finest defense of photography, highlighting its argument that photography allows for self-expression through the unmechanical use of the camera.

goodreads_match.title: Port of New York
goodreads_match.description: A collection of essays on American artists and writers, including a notable chapter on photographer Alfred Stieglitz.

raw.author: Schopenhauer
contexts: That the outer man is a picture of the inner, and the face an expression and revelation of the whole character, is a presumption likely enough in itself, and therefore a safe one to go on; borne out as it is by the fact that people are always anxious to see anyone who has made himself famous.. Photography…offers the most complete satisfaction of our curiosity. —Schopenhauer
commentaries: The author quotes Schopenhauer to connect the philosophical idea of outward appearance reflecting inner character to the function of photography.

raw.title: Pictorial Effect in Photography
raw.author: Henry Peach Robinson
contexts: the most famous of the nineteenth-century art photographers, Henry Peach Robinson, in his book Pictorial Effect in Photography (1869).
commentaries: The author references Robinson's book as a source for the positive original meaning of 'pictorial' in photography.

goodreads_match.title: Pictorial Effect in Photography
goodreads_match.description: A foundational text on art photography by Henry Peach Robinson, advocating for photography as a fine art through composition and technique.
